channel.title: Gender on It's Pronounced Metrosexual
channel.description: Recent content in Gender on It's Pronounced Metrosexual

item.title: Defining LGBTQ+
item.description: Defining LBGTQ+ is a helpful guide for getting a grasp on the terminology of gender and sexuality. It includes definitions for lots of terms, explainers for how to use them, and more! Now, before you get too excited, it‚Äôs not really a book-book.

item.title: New E-Book: Defining LGBTQ+
item.description: Hi friends! I‚Äôm going to keep this short. I just put together an E-Book called ‚ÄúDefining LGBTQ+.‚Äù It‚Äôs a guide to gender and sexuality terminology, based on my article Comprehensive List of LGBTQ+ Vocabulary Definitions, which was based on the glossary from my first book (A Guide to Gender), that grew into a collaboration with Meg Bolger (The Safe Zone Project) and thousands of you.

item.title: Why Think of Gender on Scales Instead of a Spectrum?
item.description:
When it comes to gender, most people have a similar understanding of it in their minds.

It looks something like this:

item.title: The Genderbread Person version 4
item.description: A few hundred workshops, three years, and one book edition later, I‚Äôm happy to finally publish here my 4th version of the Genderbread Person. Check it out, download it, and share it with your educator friend who is still using v3.

item.title: Yes, gender is a social construction. No, that doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs not real.
item.description:
Gender is¬†a social construction.

Even if you take the most extreme¬†biological determinist stance (which a lot of the ‚Äúgender isn‚Äôt a social construction‚Äù crowd take), you cannot deny the following:

  • What it means to be a¬†‚Äúwoman‚Äù or ‚Äúman‚Äù changes over time (often within the timeframe of a generation ‚Äî ask your grandparents if you don‚Äôt believe me).
  • Further, right now, the traits associated with each of those roles are different in different parts of the world (watch a sitcom from another country if you don‚Äôt believe me).

If our understanding of gender changes faster than our biology could possibly evolve, and currently exists in many forms around the world reflecting cultural differences, it‚Äôs socially constructed. End of argument. That‚Äôs what those two words, combined,¬†mean.

And gender is real.

Just because something‚Äôs a social construction doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs not real (despite many fellow ‚Äúsocial construction‚Äù folks saying so).

item.title: Self-Guided Foundational Safe Zone Training
item.description: “Learn about your first impressions of LGBTQ+ people, core vocabulary, gender & sexuality theory, privilege & coming out, and get your questions answered.” That's from the course description, and does a good job of summing this up. I co-created this course with Meg Bolger based on our years of experience facilitating countless in-person Safe Zone workshops.

item.title: A Few Pronoun Best [Preferred?] Practices
item.description: Pronouns: reentering prominence in many people‚Äôs lives for the first time since grammar school. How do we do them best? What should we avoid? A couple things to keep in mind up front: Pronouns replace people‚Äôs names (e.g., ‚ÄúSam is nice‚Äù ?

item.title: One Huge Prickly Reason Why Anti-LGBTQ Folks Don‚Äôt Change Their Views
item.description: I need you to take a leap with me. Leap into the shoes of someone who has walked through their life knowing that being gay, being bi, lesbian, or pan, or that being non-binary, gender non-conforming, or trans ‚Äî that being different, different from straight, different from cisgender ‚Äî is wrong.

item.title: What's the best way to view gender? As a Spectrum? Continuums?
item.description: I was invited to give a Nerd Nite talk and speak about the subject I nerd out about the most: gender. And I got to talk about a lot of the dimensions of my work that I usually don't – stuff that usually stays behind the scenes.

item.title: Let‚Äôs Talk About Bathrooms
item.description: In the winter of 2013, I was bouncing around North America attending town halls. I was invited by local activists, trans* folks, and advocacy groups who wanted me to hear about or weigh in on a discussion that was taking center stage in their communities.

item.title: A Guide to Gender (2nd Edition)
item.description: The first edition was featured as #1 best-seller in Gender on Amazon, and is being used by gender studies & sociology professors on 3 continents. Now with a new foreword by the author, brand new chapters, fixed tpyos, and more gender!

item.title: The Genderbread Person version 3
item.description: Taking the lessons learned from version 2, and applying them to sexuality in a more meaningful way, here‚Äôs my best rendition¬†of¬†the genderbread person yet. üíåMost Wednesdays I publish new Social Justice, Gender, & Sexuality Resources. Get the Email. Someone pointed out that I hadn‚Äôt shared this here yet, even though it‚Äôs been _out¬†_for awhile.

item.title: Your Ally is Someone Who‚Ä¶ (A Few Ways to Be #BetterAllies)
item.description: To celebrate GLSEN‚Äòs Ally Week, It Gets Better and I put our heads¬†together¬†to create a series of images. These comics exemplify what¬†_they¬†_described as the top traits of better allies, and in my best ally fashion I used my doodling powers to elevate that¬†message.

item.title: How the Gender Neutral Bathroom Sign I Made is Being Manufactured and Donated to Colleges
item.description: A few¬†months ago I [sarcastically] threw my hat into the Gender Neutral Bathroom Signage ring. I called that article a coping mechanism to help me deal with a current frustration. But thanks to you, the magic of the internet, and the fine folks at My Door Sign, it became¬†a thing.

item.title: Dear White, Straight, Cisgender, Man People: You Are Privileged
item.description: I‚Äôve written about privilege here, and I‚Äôve written my own privilege lists, inspired by Peggy McIntosh (blame her!), which have garnered a lot of hullabaloo on my site. Now, there seems to be a groundswell of backlash, where privileged people (like this super privileged Princeton student) are ‚Äúdenouncing their privilege‚Äù and ‚Äúfinally standing up for straight white guys‚Äù (HAHAHA).

item.title: Guerrilla Activism: Printable Gender Neutral Bathroom Signs Project
item.description: I wrote this post¬†and made the included graphic yesterday in a moment of what I call using humor for self-preservation. I was frustrated with the gender neutral bathroom sign ‚Äúdebate‚Äù and reached my tipping point. But, as several people have pointed out, like Fenix in the comments of that post, maybe it‚Äôs not such a terrible idea:

item.title: Solution for the ‚ÄúConfusing‚Äù Gender Neutral Toilet Sign Issue
item.description: A while ago I had the opportunity to sit in on some meetings where a group was lobbying their state legislators for gender neutral bathrooms. Recently, I attended a town hall where the same issue came up. In both cases, the elected officials were flabbergasted.

item.title: 15+ Fantastic Resources for Talking about ‚ÄúHomosexuality‚Äù (i.e., LGBTQ people) and The Bible
item.description: Only a tiny, tiny part of the bible can even be argued to reference ‚Äúhomosexuality‚Äù (and that argument, in a few of the verses in particular, is worth looking into), yet it seems like whenever we hear about the Bible in the news it‚Äôs being slammed against LGBTQ equality.

item.title: 9+ Silly Gender Comics I drew in 5 Minutes or Less
item.description: I made all of these comics for my book. Some of them are in there. Some didn‚Äôt make the cut. And many more that aren‚Äôt here did. Hope they give you a gender-equity giggle.

item.title: My TED Talk: Understanding the Complexities of Gender
item.description: I had the honor of being asked to give another TEDx talk, and they let me do it all about gender. You can watch the video below, and see as I try to condense hundreds of pages of my book into 16 minutes of comprehensible, enjoyable, and sometimes-rhyming words.

item.title: 30+ Examples of Masculine Dude (‚ÄúBro‚Äù) Privileges
item.description: I‚Äôve written a few privilege lists, several of which are about privileged identities I possess. They are serious articles that provide a couple hundred examples of systemic oppression (in the US and elsewhere). This article is not that. I ask that you please humor me as I take a moment to address the many privileges I¬†_don‚Äôt¬†_have access to, due to my gender expression/ metrosexuality.

item.title: Comprehensive* List of LGBTQ+ Vocabulary Definitions
item.description: *This list is neither comprehensive nor inviolable, but it‚Äôs a work in progress toward those goals. With identity terms, trust the person who is using the term and their definition of it above any dictionary. These definitions are the creation of a cultural commons: emails, online discussions, and in-person chats, with the initial curation being mine, then growing into a collaboration between Meg Bolger and me at¬†TheSafeZoneProject.

item.title: 5 Reasons Why So Many People Believe Feminism Hates Men and Why They‚Äôre Not True
item.description:
‚ÄúThe feminist agenda is not about equal rights for women. It is about a socialist, anti-family political movement that encourages women to leave their husbands, kill their children, practice witchcraft, destroy capitalism, and become lesbians.‚Äù

Pat Robertson famously said this in the 90s, and the sentiment still rings as true in the ears of many today. ¬†It‚Äôs an understatement to say that¬†feminism has a bad rap.

Feminism doesn‚Äôt hate men.

So why do so many people think feminism = man-hating? Let‚Äôs look at a few explanations for this fallacy.

item.title: Gender Inequality: Equal Education, Unequal Pay
item.description: This fantastic graphic was created and emailed to me by LearnStuff.com. Big thanks to them for sharing! ¬†

item.title: 30+ Examples of Male Privileges
item.description: Following is a list of male privileges. If you are male (and a man), listed below are benefits that result from being born with that gender and sex. If you identify as a man, there‚Äôs a good chance you‚Äôve never thought about these things.

item.title: How you can make the gender question on an application form more inclusive
item.description: A lot of people are unsure of how to make an inclusive gender or sex question on a form, and default to ‚Äúare you male or female?‚Äù ¬†Let‚Äôs not do that. ¬†Read on for some best practices and suggestions to make your forms more gender inclusive.

item.title: What does the asterisk in ‚Äútrans*‚Äù stand for?
item.description: A few people have asked why I write ‚Äútrans*‚Äù (with the asterisk) instead of just ‚Äútrans‚Äù when referring to trans* folks on my site. Well, I‚Äôm happy to answer that! üíåMost Wednesdays I publish new Social Justice, Gender, & Sexuality Resources.

item.title: 5+ Ways to Make Our World More Trans*-Friendly
item.description:
We live in a world that recognizes two options for gender. ¬†If you‚Äôre not exactly ‚Äúman‚Äù or ‚Äúwoman‚Äù you‚Äôre going to have a hard time finding your place, because right now there isn‚Äôt a place¬†for you. ¬†Let‚Äôs change that.

Following is a list of suggestions to make the world a bit less binary and a lot more transgender inclusive. ¬†Read ‚Äôem, live ‚Äôem, and add to ‚Äôem in the comments below.

item.title: The Genderbread Person version 2
item.description: Hundreds of comments, ditto emails, ditto Facebook messages and Twitter tweeters and in-person holla-atchas and I feel like I‚Äôm finally in a place to release this. I give you the new and improved Genderbread Person! (click for larger size) Depending on what you folks have to say after checking this out and reading the rationale below, I‚Äôll be updating the Breaking through the Binary article and uploading a printer-friendly version of the new graphic.

item.title: Sexual Orientation for the Genderqueer Person
item.description:
We understand that sexual orientation and gender are separate concepts. ¬†This is something that is relatively easily understood within the contexts of cisgender identities. ¬†But how does sexual orientation ‚Äúwork‚Äù for genderqueer or trans-identified peeps?

Let‚Äôs talk about it.

item.title: Little Girl Goes on a Rant Over Pink Toys
item.description: How awesome is this?! So many of us have experienced the frustration of being told something isn't for us – something we wanted to wear, or play with, or be – because of our gender. It's outrageous, and it's something that doesn't seem to be going away any time soon.

item.title: The Genderbread Person
item.description: The Genderbread Person is an infographic that breaks down gender identity, gender expression, biological sex, and sexual orientation into an easy to understand visual. It‚Äôs been around in some form for many years, and this is my whack at making an inclusive, adorable, easy to understand depiction.

item.title: 10 reasons LEGOs aren‚Äôt for girls
item.description: It‚Äôs amazing how gendered toys are. If you see an action figure, you think boy. If you see a barbie, you think girl. If you see a boy with a barbie, you think gay. And now LEGO is saying if you see LEGOs, you should think _boy ‚Äì¬†_that is, unless it‚Äôs a LadyFigs LEGO set (pictured below), then you should think girl girl girl.

item.title: 2011: A year of progress for LGBT equality [VIDEO]
item.description: Check out this great YouTube clip of MSNBC‚Äôs Thomas Roberts highlighting a ‚Äúbanner year‚Äù for LGBT rights and equality. Thanks to ThinkProgressfor uploading and sharing! Any notable events or advancements they missed? Share them in the comments below! üîå Enable Javascript to Watch Video

item.title: 30+ Examples of Cisgender Privileges
item.description: Following is a list of cisgender identity privileges. If you are cisgender, listed below are benefits that result from your alignment of identity and perceived identity. If cisgender is a new term to you, here‚Äôs how I define it in my list of LGBTQ+ vocabulary:

item.title: Breaking through the binary: Gender explained using continuums
item.description: Gender is a tough subject to tackle. ¬†There are a lot of facets to consider, a lot of pressures at play, and we have all been conditioned in such a way that our first instinct is almost unanimously wrong. ¬†But we‚Äôre going to tackle it. ¬†No, we‚Äôre going to tackle the snot¬†out of it. ¬†Coming to our aid, I would like to present to you: The Genderbread Person!

item.title: Defining a ‚ÄúMetrosexual Male‚Äù
item.description:
What does metrosexual mean? ¬†What‚Äôs the difference between a metro guy and a non-metro guy? ¬†Isn‚Äôt metrosexual just another word for gay? ¬†Is your ringtone from Kimpossible? ¬†These are questions I find myself answering on a semi-daily basis, and I‚Äôll be answering them all and more here, now, in the first and only‚Ä¶

Most Comprehensive Blog Post about Metrosexuality Ever Written (probably)

There‚Äôs a lot more to metrosexuality than well-fitting jeans, plucked unibrow hairs, and beautiful, flowing hair. ¬†Those are givens, sure, but it goes a bit deeper. ¬†Heck, there‚Äôs even a bit of history behind the whole ordeal. ¬†Let‚Äôs start with that.
